commentBody: Wow. Hardest and best Wednesday in recent memory. Nice job!
Nice!  I didn't get the theme until after I had solved, but it was a clever gimmick.  This is probably one of my favorite puzzles ever.

CORN BELT two days in a row.




EOM

Cute puzzle that gave me a good workout for a Wednesday. The gimmick was well done. I was surprised to get the happy music when I filled in the last square because I thought PRGURU must be wrong.  I had to to stare at the completed puzzle for a moment or two before I made sense of it.
Noomi? Really? Even my autocorrect disagrees.
Just stopping by to start the complaint thread about the AMOR/NOOMI crossing. ;)
Had supernovas until the end. Solid Wednesday!
Got Dividing lines, all elbows, but couldn’t get past character (arc) til the end. Not one of my best Wednesday times
That was tough for a Weds but I dug it
Thursday tough
Harder than usual for a Wednesday. But who doesn’t love a challenge—especially when it’s unexpected!

I was definitely on the constructors’ wavelength on this one. My only error on the first run through the acrosses was entering tepId for UNHIP and then realizing it was actually the answer for 35D. I loved those two answers crossing each other. I thought TOOTH for canine that bites was clever as well. Rebecca and Adam, BE A PAL and collaborate more often. I truly enjoyed this one!

Really like REGRESSIONCURVES.

Those used to be my life.

Nothing TEPID about today’s puzzle.  Five clever theme answers supported by some outstanding wordplay:

Do a spit take?
Starter starter?
Certain blue note??

Rebecca and Adam, give us SOMM more!
Took me 21 minutes, about twice my usual Wednesday time. I thought I was in the twilight zone. The combination of cluing and theme threw me for some loops. 🤷🏼‍♂️ But respect to the constructors!

Whoa, indeed!

That sure was a sweet little solve.
More lift than stoop - the way we like 'em.

Thank you Rebecca Goldstein and Adam Wagner for that gem of a Wednesday grid.

"Are they paying you for your regression line?"
"Yeah, I get residuals."

(I need some more math puns, stat!)

I support tougher Tuesday puzzles! 
And Mondays too for that matter.
Very fun and a nice little challenge.

Very tough. And very cool (or hot, or hip.) I expect nothing less from Rebecca Goldstein and Adam Wagner. Always, my experience with their individual puzzles is that I'll never finish them, until I do (though I did do a check puzzle in the end because SPERNOVAs got me good.) The amount of misdirects was challenging but completely thrilling. Fabulous ride. Thank you so much, Rebecca and Adam – for the puzzle and for making me revisit this: https://youtu.be/kBYHwH1Vb-c?si=bZIvukbUH8Naqv6Z

I came to say two things really. 

The first one is that that was pleasantly challenging, taking a bit under 5 minutes longer than my average. In the end I had to flyspeck through it to realise that 28D had to be AMOR, not AMaR, as NaOMI made it seem.  (Even then, I didn't understand ATA till I read the wordplay column). 

Second thing I came here to do is to gripe about 5D in the mini. I could accept "Bottles of pop" as a clue (with or without an "e.g."), but not "Pop bottles, e.g.". 

The containers are not their contents!

Personally, I liked clue to 36D.
50D Really? It seems like a stretch but next time I walk through security, I will try to impress the agent by calling the item as such.
Wednesdays are the toughest days to clue for. Most are too easy (usually too many gimmes) or the gimmick is cloying. This was one of the best Wednesday puzzles I can remember. Kudos.
This one was so fun! First time in awhile I’ve noticed so many clues and answers that aren’t frequently used but are still the right difficulty. Nice one
“Supernovae” is actually the standard plural for those of us who talk about them in our day jobs!
Thanks, Sam, for confirming what I was experiencing. This was an exceptionally challenging Wednesday puzzle. Not a complaint, just an acknowledgment! Consider me enlightened on many levels!

CORN BELT again, dear? The better to make AREPAS, I suppose.

Another Worthy Wednesday, thanks Rebbeca and Adam.

RIRI is reduplicated - it's a duplication of the shortened name word Ri. ISIS is not reduplicated, it's a single morpheme, not one where either syllable in  has its own extractable meaning

Sorry, had to weigh in with the linguistics perspective. Good puzzle

I solved it under my average (before anyone accuses me of being sore about the puzzle because I didn’t solve it) but some of these clues were really bad..2010 documentary trilogy about a wine exam? I took little pleasure in this one. 

Also I didn’t get the theme. What the shaded letters have to do with elbows is beyond me.

In a state of dejection, I had to hand my phone over to my wife when the areas NW and directly N had me stumped. She dealt with it with gusto.

I personally found the whole puzzle very hard, because, for example, I have no idea what a scatter plot or REGRESSION CURVE is, so that whole row remained incomplete for a long time. Also, the clues were not on my wavelength, at all.

It was a fine puzzle - I just was not its optimal solver 😉. My wife and I solved without lookups, but it took as long as a Friday or Saturday - mostly because of how much I struggled before giving up and seeking help with the smarter person of the household.

Oh, I loved this so, *so* much…

So much wordplay—and on a Wednesday, no less! 

Lately, overall, it has felt like an intended dearth of playfulness, like our editors had taken a wrong turn somewhere off the wordplay highway and were now heading down the dusty road of literalness. And then we had gems like Mr. Quigley’s Sunday—and, in fact, I remember all of last week as above par. 

And such a treat today. 

Thank you, Rebecca and Adam, for making me smile before I even ground the morning beans.

What can I say but GRR.  In the end, I figured it out, but it wasn't easy.  Forgot she was NOOMI and not Roomi, and couldn't read the TEA leaves.  Otherwise, I managed to get it done, though deeply puzzled most of the time.  (e.g., never hear of SOMM).
The juxtaposition of RON Howard and "I've made a huge mistake!" made this Arrested Development fan very happy. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GwQW3KW3DCc
Anyone else have "MON" for Starter starter? (As kn the starting letters of the starting day of the week). Don't get why NON makes sense
I thought the clueing was a bit tough for a Wednesday puzzle. Not really an enjoyable puzzle for me.

"...it won’t surprise you to learn that Rebecca and I wanted to make this theme more difficult."

I found it was pleasantly difficult for a Wednesday. Looking at my times this year, it took me longer than 4 Saturdays did, than 9 Fridays, and 10 Thursdays.

Adding to my enjoyment, I used the theme to help me solve. (More often, the theme is checked/understood after solving.)

If only some of the super easy late-week puzzles this year offered as much of a challenge as this Wednesday!

Thanks for the correct spelling of SUPERNOVAE 

In the real world we do use supernovae 

😀

Nice puzzle. More work than a normal Wednesday but I agree with Sam that it was an excellent puzzle.
Solid puzzle but I think the cryptic-y ones were overreaching a little and were too obscure in many cases. Dial them down a bit and it’d’ve been a solid Wednesday puzzle.

Excellent puzzle!  Just what I expect from Rebecca and Adam.
  
The fact that only 10 of their original clues were edited shows what pros they are.

Whew. Amazing piece of construction but... 11 debut answers in this one and 5 others that have only appeared once or twice before, and... some of those were completely unfamiliar to me: NOOMI, PRGURU, SOMM etc.  

Anyway, had to cheat more than a bit to get through this and almost everyone else found it unusually easy. Probably shouldn't count it. I'll defer to the majority. 

Might be past time for me to return to my home planet. 

....

So much Wednesday crunch!

I do like me some crunch.

Leaving for the airport in an hour to fly to
younger son’s graduation from 
medical school tomorrow.
Then Friday night we fly back with him, 
because older son’s wedding is 
Saturday afternoon.

1,000 miles apart.
45 hours between events.
And our flights keep getting changed.
And flying makes me nervous.
And the wedding is a bit of a circus.
And…

Wish me luck?
Trying to enjoy these big, happy events
and look past all the chaos that is surrounding them!

But bringing my iPad.
Not doing this week without my puzzle!
Not no-how!

Happy hump day all!
I liked this one a lot, except I've never heard anyone ever say, "TSA bin". It's just a bin. Maybe it's a regional thing.
First Wednesday in a long time I gave up on. Not fun.

All who know me, know I champion those Latinate plurals, and I would about as likely to say "supernovas" as I would say "pia maters" or "irises," which I do, all the time, "out in the real world."

Well, for once, "the real world" appears to agree with me! Sam, according to Ngram viewer, "supernovae" has "supernovas" beat by .00001%, which I gather is a big deal in Ngram-land. ("Supernovæ," with the ligature, scarcely places--People! It's Alt-right+z! I see I still have my work cut out for me.)

According to Ngram, "supernovae" hit its peak--.000035%--in 1984, just about the time Yours Truly was bursting onto the scene--coincidence? I think not.

I keep my stats (yep, nerd) and this Wednesday took me almost 3 minutes longer (in percentages, that's over 25% btw) than the next most difficult Wednesday, covering a period of over 5 years.  I remember a few months back a similar thing happened, and wonder if some kind of adjustment is happening. Having "GASX," "PRGURU," and "AREPAS" bordering each other is sadistic. Often, difficult puzzles are fun to solve. This was not one of those.

Just a blitz of creativity in this one!

First, the cluing.  It felt as though Rebecca and Adam put in the time to make every single clue shine.  Devilishness abounded in wordplay wit, and misdirection.  

Then, coming up with this crackling theme, never done before.  And delivering -- generating worthy theme answers plus having them fit the demands of symmetry.  Wow! 

Finally, plumping up that goodness with a remarkable level of freshness. Three of the four theme answers are NYT debuts.  Three of the four vertical 10-letter longs are debuts.  A grid with eleven debuts plus a pair of once-befores and another pair of twice-befores.  Wow again!

Memorable moment: Putting in TEPID for [Not hot or cool], only to erase it ten seconds later and insert it for [Lukewarm].

Bonuses: Five double-Os, LEE and EEL in the SE, a backward ISIS to go with RIRI, and an extra column.

Humor, skill, and polish in the box today.  This was one of those special ones.  Thank you so much, Rebecca and Adam!

I'm glad I don't have a breakfast partner, because they would have had to put up with me muttering "OOO SAYSSSS  EYES ELLS" trying to sound out the theme, and failing, humming the sort-of National Anthem.
I got ATA but didn't get it until I read the explanation. And as others have surely noted, TSA bin is not terminology I've ever heard but it makes sense.

Cute theme and today's prize goes to the clues.  Would have preferred the original clue for the temperament torii.  NE the last to fall:  knew is was XRAY something but had trouble focusing.    Nice one and thanks.
Other than as (arguable) misdirection, I do not understand the need for an exclamation point for the clue "Stay there."

Great wordplay on so many clues!
Struggled with many, but eventually
goT The crosses.

"Time of one's life" should have carried a question mark. Especially since AGE crosses a product name, PRGURU and AREPAS.

Without the question mark, the clue suggests ERA, which I suspect many of us had first. And without the question mark, AGE really doesn't fit "Time of one's life". Misdirection is fine, but I think this clue was certainly questionable---pun intended.

Nice puzzle, with a very clever theme. Never expected to see REGRESSIONCURVES in a crossword puzzle. Quite the South American vibe here, with potatoes from PERU, Colombian cakes, and a park in ARG. Liked this one a lot, and a good workout for me after yesterday's personal best time.
Clearly, the Akron-Canton Airport has hired a truly effective PR guru: https://www.travelpulse.com/news/technology/ohio-airport-debuts-self-cleaning-tsa-bins
Corn belt week!  Nice puzzle.
I don't think the SOMM series is a trilogy, SOMM: Cup of Salvation seems to be the fourth in the series. But that was from 2023, so does that mean "2010s [...] trilogy" is still accurate?
This one was tough-but-solvable for me, which is exactly what I appreciate.
NOOMI crossing AMOR broke my streak. Another NYT proper noun trivia fest.

A very cleverly done puzzle, for sure. Only a few times did the crosses help. I had to keep my sense of humor on the forefront  during this one, as well as several look-ups.

1A… ptui! Never would have guessed an eye rhyme (I had to look up “Words that look like they should rhyme but do not”)

Hoar and Hora confuse me to no end (both could be mildly derogatory, if improperly used), pero gracias a Parque Nacional Los Glaciares, my confusion terminology termino rapidamente. Too bad potatoes didn't originate there.

There is no Barnyard graduate in Animal Farm, but a Barnard graduate(!). Wow, I need to clean my specs.

As with many puzzles with highlighted squares, the shaded letters only made sense *after* the word was filled in. Not much help there, I should have read Sam Corbin’s suggestion *before* attacking today’s challenge.

That certain blue note… Harold Melvin? A flatted 3rd? But noooo. I'm sooo unhip to the jive.

Hardest Wednesday in a long time! PRGURU was terrific; the letters seemed so unlikely as that part of the grid came together. I filled in ATA but did not understand it until reading Wordplay, and was unaware of SOMM, so they were both problems as they seem nonsensical as strings of letters. A big wrench in the works for me was that I kept trying to find some clue from the theme, and that was waste of time. Would have preferred for the theme to have more meat to it as what's there seems pretty superficial.
Toughest Wednesday I've seen in  a long, long time! PRGURU baffled me for way longer than it should've.

OooooKAY...  I got the puzzle, but I didn't "get" the puzzle, until ("Oh, please, don't let it be...")...but Yep, that was the 'theme' ...or the 'trick'....or the 'point'....

I prefer just to look at this as a themeless puzzle with a very puzzling 1D entry/clue and a new-to-me thing (REGRESSION CHARTS? Oops CURVES) for which I had to enlist the assistance of DHubby, who looks instead for a straight line, apparently.

Nit Department:
In the YouTube clips, OSPREYS are going after (and catchinng) much more substantial pelagic prey....and I guess freshwater as well.
STOOP for "Debase oneself" (?one's self?)--  Not really.  BOW or PROSTRATE or GROVEL, maybe.  "She STOOPs to conquer" hardly suggests debasement.  And if you have small children about, you'll find you often need to STOOP.
The End.
Noomi Repace was not in The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo. She was in the sequel The Girl Who Played with Fire.
“Storm center” … now, this constructor has an EYE for snappy clues.
The theme of this seemed pretty far flung to me.  C's are arcs?

Not too bad. I would never have solved the maths clue but no matter, most of the others were ok

Except “Preach!” which I don’t understand, clue or solution. 

Brand names like GASX are also so frustrating!
And RAHRAH meaning zealous? How?

Fun puzzle. I had never heard of SOMM but I looked it up and now I think I need to give it a watch! TSABIN didn't bug me but isn't the nickname for Les Miserables usually spelled LES MIZ? Interesting to me that so many found this one difficult for a Wednesday (and XWStats agrees). I finished right around my average time for a Wed.
This was tough for me. Just couldn’t get a foothold. Still, it was good and once I finished (with help) I realized I was making it too hard. Thanks to the constructors! See y’all tomorrow.
Speaking as the mother of a Villanova alumnus and crazy Nova fan, perhaps SUPERNOVAE refers to the Pope who is a graduate of Villanova and has the same degree as my son!  And it's Latin, to boot.

I filled in PRGURU exclusively on crosses, looked at that weird combination of letters and thought, "Well, that's clearly wrong, but I'll swing back and correct it later."

Swinging back, I thought, "Oh, now I see it."

I'm smarter than I thought,...or not!

re 46A: Lately, my Partner and I have become fond of those British TV police procedurals, and Saturday evenings will often find us watching an episode of *Vandervalk* (the reboot) or *Midsomer Murders* ("and ice cream after the second corpse!"); so the pictures-and-string idea was a gimme for me. "But I want to know where they get those photos!," he demands.
Very good puzzle. But not a Wednesday.
Did you mean to say you were getting too big for your britches?

Yup, Naomi for me, too! Who noo?

Or, from that "Guys and Dolls" number by Sinatra and Blaine:

Call a lawyer and sue me, Noomi
What can you do me
I love you
Give a holler and hate me, hate me
Go ahead and hate me

The last half hour, I was a fool to give to you
Alright already, I got Steve Nicks
Alright already, it's true
So nooo, so sue me, Noomi
What can you do me?

Yup, Naomi for me too. Who noo?

Or, as Sinatra and Blaine put it in Guys and Dolls:

Call a lawyer and sue me, Noomi
What can you do me
I love you
Give a holler and rate me, debate me
Go ahead and play me

The last half hour of my life I was a fool to give to you
Alright already, I got Steve Nicks
Alright already, it's true
So noo, so sue me, Noomi
What can you do me?

***

I also had "In a bin" for a long time, since nobody says TSA bin, do they? Maybe those who magically find foot rests under the seats in front of them say TSA bin!  Loved tepid / unhip cluing.  Character arcs was pretty awesome. The return of cornbelt was eerie. The cluing for "eye" didn't have that touch of AI I've come to expect, but Goldstein & Wagner would not STOOP so low! Now THAT would be a regression curve.
Usually I am the one stumped by the name in these puzzles, but apparently today I was in the minority (?) for whom Noomi was a gimme. A nice change! A situation not soon to be repeated, probably :D
I just didn’t like this one. 21 minutes over my average.  Ugh.
Harder than a typical Wednesday but nothing too crazy. The theme wasn't my favorite.
Arepas are Venezuelan.

Romped through this one as fast as I could type, then died in the NE.
Never heard of GASX or AREPAS, PR GURU and XRAY CAMERA are alien phrases to me, and I thought the "samoyed" was an actual Siberian person (despite the lack of capitalization), never having heard of the dog breed.
Sigh.

Today's crossword inspired anecdote:

The Samoyed are a Siberian people discussed in Anna Reid's "The Shaman's Coat: A Native History Of Siberia". When I bought that book from an on-line store, I received an unusual recommendation:

"People who bought The Shaman's Coat also bought The Hidden Code Of Cryptic Crosswords."

Presumably someone had once bought both books.
But it was a fine recommendation for me, so I also bought the cryptic crossword book. Which  presumably has firmly convinced the recommendations algorithm that these two books have a lot in common.
This was a bit too tough for a Wednesday for me.  I muddled through but missed my under 10 minutes goal (I am a horrible typist, btw). Oh well another one in the books!

It's interesting to me because this puzzle was pretty straightforward for me - no look ups at all. I had to ponder a few times, change a few letters here and there but that's all. 

But there are lots of puzzles that I think are insanely difficult and others breeze through in single digit minutes. It's just how our brains work, and which phrases and references are familiar!

Thanks this was a fun one!
Probably my slowest Wednesday ever, but I enjoyed the cluing (baffling as a few were to me) and theme.  Also enjoyed great column by Sam and both constructor comments.  Thanks!
Not a fan of this one.  Obscure names, obtuse clueing. Certainly not a typical Wednesday for me.

Just finished today’s NYT crossword by Rebecca Goldstein and Adam Wagner—what a clever and visually satisfying solve! The theme was a standout, with shaded letters forming shapes that matched the answers: O’s for MOOD RINGS, C’s for CHARACTER ARCS, S’s for REGRESSION CURVES, I’s for DIVIDING LINES, and L’s for ALL ELBOWS. It felt like solving a mini art piece.
The fill was smooth, with fun clues like PR GURU (“Spin instructor?”) and BE A PAL (“Come on, help me out”). Online chatter seems to agree—lots of praise for the inventive theme and clean execution. Some noted the visuals made the theme easier to crack, which helped me too.
If I had one nit, it’s that the theme density made a few spots feel tight. But overall, this was a refreshing, smart midweek puzzle. Big kudos to the constructors!

Sigh. My replies are not showing up, so I'm posting a separate comment.

Re SOMM and the clue, I was asking so I can learn more about cluing conventions and get better at solving crosswords. I wanted to know if the "trilogy" was an oversight given there are 4 movies, or intentional because 3 of them were in 2010. Knowing NYT I'm gonna go with the latter and learn from this that, for example, "2010s movie franchise with 4 installments" could well be THEHUNGERGAMES, in a future puzzle.

Clever theme!

Still under my average time -- I've gotten better and the puzzles have gotten easier -- but not by as much as usual for a Wednesday!

That was fun!

Well, I fell as if I just went through a Wednesday character arc! Excellent challenge...though I admit I've never heard of regression curves...but I suppose that's what the USA is going through since the election. May we create a dividing line from it next election!! Amen sisters and brothers!

Good one. No coddling, either in the clues or the theme. Little problem with Dragon Tattoo reference because I was thinking of Mara Rooney-Daniel Craig English version but Amor pulled me through.

One question I'm too lazy to check. Yesterday I did a puzzle with "cornbelt" in it. Since I often go back to the archive and do puzzles I probably solved 20 years ago in a hard copy NYT back in NYC I can't recall if the word appears in 2 consecutive dailies or if it was in the archived puzzle
this puzzle so hard I had to call my mom

I did close to my normal on this but I didn't get most of the clever clues. I solved them by the cross and then saw it. For some, for others I didn't realize what I'd done until I read this description. I need to get better at this.

I don't know... this one came fairly smoothly for me after the first full round yielded very little. As I started to just work in the various sections, it filled in pretty easily for me. Some things I had to rip out to see clearly but it all worked out well—despite a very nasty head cold. I enjoyed the puzzle a lot, particularly the clues and wordplay. The theme was a bit meh to me. I'd have liked it to be a bit more challenging, as Adam mentioned in the constructor notes. 

If you read most of my comments, I think you'll agree that I'm not very braggadocious (nor have I much reason to be) so I don't say any of the above in that spirit. It's just that I saw on XWordstats and in the comments I've lightly perused that this was considered very hard—but it wasn't to me, and so often what seems easy to others is much harder for me? 

I mean, I know we all differ, but this happens often enough that I wonder what's wrong with my brain.

Note to self - next time don’t do one of Rebecca and Adam’s grids when you’re still in bed and the melatonin hasn’t worn off yet. My brain was not prepared.

I might not have got to this one before tomorrow’s dropped, though, so I guess my gold star streak was going to end one way or another.
As a Midwest native, I was delighted to see CORNBELT pop up two days in a row. Let's keep it up!

Didn't like the themed clues/answers here. "Regression Curves" was particularly bad.  Also, Hotel and Nest didn't really fit well with the clues.  I think the authors got a little too cute with this one.
Is today Saturday and no one told me to take the day off?
All you have do to make a crossword difficult is give bad clues.
Got the puzzle done with no look-ups, but Never figured out the theme. So here I am. Meh.
Maybe I’m just sheltered, but… blue note? What?

I'm sufficiently curious about XRAY CAMERA to post afresh here, since my previous comment is concealed by the current bug that conceals stuff.

Does anyone actually call the thing in the dentist's office an XRAY CAMERA? It's not an expression I've ever heard, and it doesn't quite make sense in terms of how the thing works. (Then again, lots of things have names that don't make sense.)

In these parts, we have the machine that generates the x-rays (called, well, the "x-ray machine") and an x-ray detector on to which the x-ray machine projects the shadow of your teeth and bones, which is the plate that tucks into your mouth, containing (in the old days) film, and nowadays digital sensors.

Hardest Wednesday puzzle in a long, long time.  Sometimes, due to a combination of odd cluing, too many puns, oddly worded answers (xraycamera????) and ones that I just don't know/can't get, I find a puzzle annoying and difficult.  At least for me, this one was both.  More like a Friday level of difficulty.

Back online after a long day, and immediately burst out laughing, chortling at Sam's "Debase" photo!

The theme play with letters was fun, not necessary to the solve IMO, but rather like Easter Eggs in the puzzle, a final fillip.

Thanks, Rebecca and Adam.

A couple of late puzzle finds. Here's one of them - a Sunday from July 6, 2003 by Robert H. Wolfe with the title "Film splicing." A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Lunch fears?" HIGHNOONANXIETY "First lady's hype?" ALLTHATJAZZABOUTEVE "Skinny, dejected football player?" THETHINBLUELINEMAN And some other theme answers: TWOWOMENFORTHEROAD THEBIGEASYSLEEP Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/6/2003&g=61&d=A ...
The theme was really lame imo, and the cluing got tedious with all the wordplay. Not fun at all.

Stay there!

To me, that deliberately misleading exclamation mark makes me hear someone shouting.

Having read so many comments about how hard this puzzle was, I had to write that I did not find it particularly hard. I did have trouble with the NE corner in the morning but came back after work and solved it quickly. Nothing like a fresh perspective. Having successfully solved it, it did take me a minute or two to figure out the theme.
Unpleasant.

Got through it without lookups, but meaninglessly obtuse cluing made it a slog. Clue for AT A was really bad. Glad to see Stevie NICKS in there, saw her at MSG a couple years ago and it was incredible. One of the greatest singers of all time.

At almost 33 minutes for an unaided solve, this was more of a Wednesday and a half, maybe even a Wednesday and three quarters.

But I liked it well enough. 

It was reasonably entertaining, and using the theme to figure some things out was satisfying.

Finally!

My meager knowledge is statistics paid off!

I've been waiting for this day for at least a year.

Funny though, I wanted to put in "regression line."
Like Sam, I too was overthinking the theme and it took me some time to see the simplicity of what was going on. I enjoyed the ride though. Thanks, Rebecca and Adam. 😊

I enjoyed this one. X-RAY CAMERA was last to fall:)
Thanks to Rebecca and Adam. Always a pleasure and great constructor notes haha!

Unlike many commenters, I didn't find this puzzle any harder than usual for a Wednesday. FWIW, I didn't fully understand the theme until after solving and reading this column, so the themed clues neither helped nor hindered me. (Other than on Mondays and Minis, I always do the Down clues first, so by the time I read said themed clues I'd already filled in some crosses.)
Agree with Sam, "at a" as the answer for "one-time connection" is devious and brilliant.

I like the theme! It clicked for me once I got “character arcs” and helped me solve “all elbows” and “dividing lines” since I then knew all the gray boxes had to be the same. This allowed me to realize I needed “tsa bin” rather than “in a bin” - agree with others that I’ve never called this a tsa bin. Still took a while to get regression curve, and I’m an economist….
not my favourite Wednesday
That was a tough Wednesday! Especially the NE quadrant. Finally came together when I remembered GASX. And finally solved it on the bizarre cross of AMOR and NOOMI.

I’m sorry if someone else has already addressed this, but I read through approx 1/3 of the top comments and didn’t see anything regarding XRAYCAMERA. There really isn’t such a thing and even if there was, it’s certainly not what a dentist would use to image your teeth. An X-ray machine generates x-rays that are beamed at a subject and then detected (now) digitally by an imaging plate (not a camera) that in turn creates a radiograph. The image should NOT be called an x-ray. This is one of those things that everyone gets wrong so often, it’s become standard. (Kinda like how the first annual event of something is the second time it’s occurred, not the first). 
The only medical imaging modality that actually uses a “camera” is Nuclear Medicine, where a gamma camera (or scintillation detector) only detects and counts the light (gamma rays) being emitted by an outside source (ie the patient). Unlike an x-ray or CT machine, the gamma camera does not generate any radiation.
I know I’m shouting into the void on this one, but let’s not perpetuate incorrect terms if we can help it.
Your jump to links don’t work.

CORN BELT as an answer two days in a row? What are the chances.
Great puzzle! I loved the theme.
Never heard of Blue being used to mean risqué. Is it regional? Generational?

@Jake

Agreed!

I was lost in so many spots. Nothing connecting for the longest time.

Enjoyable challenge.

@Barry Ancona

@Andrzej let me try a non-mathy explanation of scatter plots and regression curves. Draw a very long cross (what we call the X and Y axes in math, but I digress). Add a bunch of dots in various places, but to make this easier for demonstration purposes have most of them form a rough line or at least an elongated blob. Those represent the data points in a scatter plot. Now draw a line lengthwise through the approximate middle of the dots. That’s your regression curve.

As a retiree I actually have government-provided medical coverage. After a lifetime of fear, I can't tell you how much of a relief it was to qualify for Medicare, and a "Medigap" policy was affordable. I have a tiny pension ($364 a month) from a six year stretch as a union member...not much, but it helps.

I would be in bad shape had I not bought a house earlier, but I did, so rent's not an issue. I don't live in luxury, but I don't worry about where my next meal is coming from, either. And most of my career was spent in factories and warehouses.

It's a lot better than what millions of other people have waiting for them in a lot of other countries.

Hi, @Andrzej! Sorry to carp on yesterday's topics, but-- --Did you ever get a chance to look at that Stanislaw Lem short story I linked yesterday? I wonder what your take was. I have often wondered what Lem reads like in Polish, and how translators handle all the wordplay and neologisms. Many of them are based on Latinate techno-jargon, and I'd guess a word like "narcissator" (a type of electronic circuit) would sound similar in the original Polish. But the rest? Apparently, Lem praised his English translator, Michael Kandel, as being "inventive in finding semantic equivalents in English in difficult cases." Here is the link again: https://gwern.net/doc/ai/poetry/1974-lem-cyberiad-trurlselectronicbard.pdf (A story which centers on AI-generated poetry--written in 1965! And it even mentions crossword puzzles (at least in English.)

@Bill

Not yet, but thanks for reminding me. Wednesdays are my busiest days - I solve the puzzle in the early morning and then I lecture and have classes for hours. Then I do some shopping, I take care of the dog. I'm usually completely drained after all that and usually just fall asleep on the couch 🤣. At present I am at the shopping stage.

@Bill

I compared the first paragraphy of the English translation with the Polish original from my bookshelf: there is a *huge* difference in style. The English has none of the charm and uniqueness of Lem's Polish.

The Polish is understated but elegantly so: it has an almost poetic flow, and the vocabulary displays Lem's touch - he often chose less common synonyms for what he was describing. All that is completely lost in the translation.

Even the subtitle is very different, stylistically. "Electronic bard" has nothing on Lem's Polish "Elektrybałt", which is pure linguistic genius. Elektry- may be understood as a prefix meaning what follows is electrical. "Rybałt" is an old Polish term for a travelling folk artist. The fact the "ry" of Elektrybałt make sense in both parts of Lem's neologism gives me a wordgasm. Also, the very inclusion of the almost ancient "rybałt" in a futuristic story is interesting in itself. None of that is reflected in "Electronic bard", at all.

@Sara

For a long time now, a few years perhaps, the NYT clock has been completely unreliable for me. (I solve on a Macbook, in Firefox browser.)

Basically, the clock keeps running; it always adds a few dozen seconds to my solve time, often a few minutes, sometimes it's *hours*.

Because my NYT stats are so unreliable, and because I'm a total xword geek, from this year I started keeping track of my solve times in my own excel worksheet.

That's how I know my solve times in such detail; I keep track myself, because the NYT clock is so unreliable.

Dave,

Indeed, no other need. 
It is "(arguable) misdirection."

@Dave

This is a less common but fairly consistent type of crossword clue. When a clue ends with “it” or “that” plus an exclamation mark, it signals that you have to answer what “it” is. 

So if the clue is “Darn it!”, the answer may be SOCK, since that’s something that should be darned. 

It is not looking for a phrase similar to “Darn it!”

If it were, the quotation marks would actually be part of the clue.

If the clue is ["Darn it!"], look for an equivalent phrase.

If the clue is [Darn it!], look for something to darn.

@Mean Old Lady I humbly offer a correction to your second nit: The source of "she stoops to conquer"--the play by Oliver Goldsmith--offers a high-status woman disguising herself as a barmaid in order to marry the man she loves. The ultimate source is a Dryden poem: "The prostrate lover, when he lowest lies, / But stoops to conquer, and but kneels to rise." Both scenarios suggest debasement--as Dryden's use of your proposed "prostrate" demonstrates.

@Mean Old Lady
Just to muddy the waters, out on the Chesapeake, I often see ospreys STOOP (dive steeply) to conquer fish, but I'm not sure any of those were EELs. I think those fish stay closer to the bottom. Anyway, it's even more impressive live than in those videos.

@NucTech

I commented twice about XRAY CAMERA, asking if any solver here was actually familiar with the term. I'd never heard it, and (like you) thought it certainly didn't describe the thing in the dentist's office. But I thought it might be a British/American usage difference.
A small number of people responded to say they were unfamiliar with the usage, which I suppose at least suggests it's not common currency among solvers here.

Some companies that produce X-ray equipment for dentistry do call their x-ray machines "X-ray cameras", and I also turned up the occasional use of the phrase in academic papers in dentistry journals. So it's a thing. Like you, I think it's an unfortunate thing.
@NucTech I said it was my last to fall.

@Madsterino I think perhaps generational? Referring to a “blue movie” is an older term for talking about pornography and I have heard my mother (a boomer) refer to things as being “a bit blue”, however it is not something that I (an older millennial) would use in conversation.
